title: The Visitation
dialogue_triumphs: Tegan lies outrageously when asked about the Doctor: 'He likes to be mysterious, although he talks a lot about Guildford. I think that's where he comes from.'
Doctor: 'How do you feel now?' Tegan: 'Groggy, sore and bad-tempered.' Doctor: 'Almost your old self.'
goofs: The android wears poorly disguised cricket gloves (cf. 'Silver Nemesis').
The miller's donkey seems to resent Mace's attention.
When Nyssa is attacked by the android, the room begins to shake before she switches on the machine.
When the Doctor is searching for the Terileptils' London base, the scanner shows a 'brown and white' 17th-century print of London's streets, rather than an image drawn up by the TARDIS' sensors.

continuity_notes.name: TARDIS
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's time machine and spacecraft
continuity_notes.current_status: Lateral balance cones are 'playing up' (probably 'temperamental solenoids'), foiling the Doctor's attempt to get Tegan back to 1981 Heathrow.

continuity_notes.name: Adric
continuity_notes.current_status: Able to recover from injuries quickly. Can pilot the TARDIS with Nyssa.

continuity_notes.name: Nyssa
continuity_notes.current_status: Able to pilot the TARDIS with Adric.

continuity_notes.name: Terileptils
continuity_notes.description: Very intelligent semi-reptilian creatures with a heightened appreciation of aesthetics and warfare
continuity_notes.current_status: Escaped from tinclavic mines on Raaga, where they were sentenced to life imprisonment.

continuity_notes.name: Sonic Screwdriver
continuity_notes.current_status: Destroyed during the events of the episode.

links: The story follows on directly from 'Kinda'
Tegan assumes that the Terileptil's interest in the TARDIS means that, like Monarch, he wants to 'ride in it' ('Four to Doomsday')
The Doctor's line 'Not again', as he faces the chop at the end of episode two, is also a reference to 'Four to Doomsday'
additional_notes: Nyssa's fluffy ear-muffs are noted as a 'Fashion Victim' item.
bottom_line: A good, hearty action romp, crisply written and engaging, although critics might say that it's too straightforward. There's only one proper character (Richard Mace), which gives Peter Davison and Michael Robbins the space to turn in a pair of lovely performances. The end result is a stylish slice of pseudo-historical nonsense.
